data.text: Is Continental Gatorskin Safe to Use on Wet Ground?

Has anyone tried the continental gatorskin? They claim it's good for all weather conditions and punctured resistant. However i feel very unsafe in wet road conditions since the back wheel breaks loose easily when i do light braking. Anyone having issues with that model aswell? I have the 32mm version and put 6bar (max.) In it.
They are a good tyre overall, 6 bar is very high pressure for that tyre size. Have you tried 5 bar instead? That should give your tyres a better purchase on the tarmac
data.author: Adam Jones

data.text: good call, might be too high pressure. I have the mind stuck in my had that i have to go max. pressure when riding roads. It felt bumpy tho when the tarmac was broken, might try less bar on a short ride. I didn't wanna risk it on a 2 days ride, it's hard to get that bar in with a Handpump. üòÖ
data.author: Maximilian Vitus Wageneder

data.text: I know people love these but for me the gatorskin tire was the worst tire I‚Äôve ever used. Impossible to get on and off, very stiff and uncomfortable ride, very flat prone and didn‚Äôt last very long. I hated them so much that I now refuse to buy any tire made by continental.
data.author: Brian Gangelhoff

data.text: wow that's a lot of hate. üòÖ I had no issues getting them on
data.author: Maximilian Vitus Wageneder

data.text: Continental tyres all size tight so it comes down to rim, it can be not too bad or a real pain.
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: Haha, it‚Äôs true. I got so many flats and they were impossible to change a tube. I‚Äôve never verbally cursed and yelled at any tire like I did at those. I don‚Äôt know if they still have the little red thread crossing on the side walls but those would come out and wrap around my brakes.
data.author: Brian Gangelhoff

data.text: it seems like they hate you as much as you hate them
data.author: Maximilian Vitus Wageneder

data.text: Gatorakins are useless in the wet. They might be hard wearing and puncture proof but not really safe if you are riding in the wet. Scrap them. If you want to stay with continental( and have really strong thumbs) 4 seasons are the way to go.
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: i wanted to have some puncture resistant ones, the gatorskin just seems sooo unsafe in wet weather... I'll look into the 4 seasons, it was also on my list
data.author: Maximilian Vitus Wageneder

data.text: I ran Vittoria rubino controls, or at least I did when I ran skinny tyres, worked well but that is anecdotal. I also care more about staying upright in corners than flats
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: seems like you can't have it all. üòÖ
data.author: Maximilian Vitus Wageneder

data.text: you can't, but I choose staying rubber side down every time
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: They are terrible - a relic from the past that‚Äôs best left there. As one of my friends says of gatorskins ‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather use old hosepipe‚Äù üòÇ If you want a good modern puncture resistant road tyre look at the Pirelli Cinturato Velo. It‚Äôs puncture resistance score is actually higher than the Gatorskin but it has performance, grip, feel and rolling resistance closer to a summer race tyre. These make excellent performance tyres for winter and poor roads, or all year round. Go tubeless too if you can.
data.author: Edd Hunt

data.text: i checked on my reliable order sites and they're only available in 28mm, didn't wanna go slimmer than 32mm sadly
data.author: Maximilian Vitus Wageneder

data.text: They are available larger, but they also come up big - I have them in 28mm and they actually measure 31mm on my wheels
data.author: Edd Hunt

data.text: They are also available in 32mm and 35mm sizes
data.author: Edd Hunt

data.text: nvm found them! Thanks for your input. Not sure if i go with them right away or wait for next season... let's see how much annoyed i get by the gatorshits üòÇ
data.author: Maximilian Vitus Wageneder

data.text: life is too short to ride gatorskins üòÇ
data.author: Edd Hunt
